Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multi-Scale Structured Solid Carriers Enabling Algae Biofuel Manufacturing in the Ocean

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) award is to test the hypothesis that micro- and meso-scale structures of solid carriers enhance attachment of algae. Such structures (for example, dimples or channels) will be fabricated on the surface of solid carriers -- the major equipment proposed for manufacturing algae biofuels in the ocean. The approach includes an experimental study of cell attachment to structured carriers, physics-based modeling of cell-carrier interactions, and prediction of the effect of carrier structures on algae attachment using the surface element integration technique. The educational objective of this proposal is to impart a system-level integration of a manufacturing-education-enhancement based theme at high school, undergraduate, and graduate levels. This will be accomplished through exposure of undergraduate and graduate students to interdisciplinary research projects, K-12 outreach through existing outreach programs, course and curriculum development in energy manufacturing, and involvement of women and minorities through mentoring programs at Kansas State University.

Knowledge obtained from this research will foster design and manufacturing of solid carriers to help realize the vision of affordable bio-based energy manufacturing. Economically viable manufacturing of algae biofuels will greatly benefit the economy and energy security, as well as society and the environment of the United States. Success of the proposed activities will help expand the role of the manufacturing research community to create a new, trillion dollar energy manufacturing industry in the United States. The interdisciplinary research will benefit engineering education at Kansas State University. Students will be exposed to two very distinct research fields -- algae molecular biology and manufacturing processes. Research results will be disseminated through journal articles, conferences, workshops, and summer programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to their extremely high oil yield, algae have been regarded as one of the most promising sources for biofuel manufacturing. However, algae biofuels are very costly with currently available methods, such as open ponds or photobioreactors, mainly due to high algae culture and harvesting costs. From a fundamental perspective, this project addressed these bottleneck issues through a new approach: solid-carrier-based algae biofuel manufacturing. The idea was to grow and harvest algae, for biofuel manufacturing, on solid carriers made of thin-sheets of metals or polymers that float in the ocean. Micro- and meso-scale structures (e.g., dimples and channels) were fabricated on the surface of the carrier by advanced manufacturing technologies, such as laser processing and incremental forming, in order to enhance cell attachment. The fundamental mechanisms of cell attachment were investigated, and cell disruption methods using ultrasound were explored to obtain lipids from cells.

The following outcomes have been achieved during the entire project period: (1) A thermodynamic model was developed to simulate algal cell attachment to solid surfaces. It revealed the relationships between surface energy and cell attachmet, and can qualitatively predict algal cell attachment to surfaces. The model was also validated by published literature data on a wider variety of microbes and materials, indicating that the model developed can be applicable in designing, selecting, and matching algal strains and solid carrier materials to enhance cell attachment. (2) To enhance the bioadhesion of algal cells on textured surfaces, two algae were studied on solid carriers made of nylon and polycarbonate with varying surface patterns. Optimum feature size was found to be close to the diameter of the cell attempting to settle. Larger or smaller feature dimensions would reduce cellular attachment. This finding can foster the design of solid carrier surfaces for enhanced cell attachment on solid surfaces. (3) In order to understand how cells interact with each other, the classical DLVO model was developed and found applicable to optimize microalgae flocculation. This knowledge can assist cell harvesting in liquid media. (4) In order to understand the effect of solid carrier material and surface roughness on microalgal cell attachment, two algae species on six different material surfaces were studied. It was found that when the surface chemical composition of the solid carriers was similar (e.g., all stainless steel), the attachment of algal cells depended largely on the surface roughness of the solid carrier, wherein rougher surfaces resulted in increased attachment. However, when materials were chemically different (e.g., glass vs. nylon vs. stainless steel), cell attachment was strongly related to the surface free energy but not the surface roughness of the solid carrier. This finding is critical in selecting solid carrier materials and surface design. (5) An untrasonic nozzle spraying system was developed and optimized to disrupt microalgal cells for effective lipid extraction. This knowledge is important to optimize cell disruption in a continuous system. (6) A method for predicting ultrasound induced microalgal cell disruption was developed. It can be utilized to design and optimize ultrasound systems for effective and efficient algal cell disruption. (7) A 3-D model of algal cell cavitation under ultrasound was developed, which can be utilized for predicting ultrasoundinduced algal cell disruption. It consequently can guide the design of sonochemical reactors and optimization of their processing conditions.

This project has advanced our understanding of the influence of material properties and multi-scale structures of solid carrier on algae attachment. Knowledge obtained will guide design of structures and determination of manufacturing methods of solid carriers, which will eventually lead to large-scale use of artificial constructs in the ocean for algae biofuel manufacturing. The findings will help realize the vision of affordable bio-based energy manufacturing. Economically viable manufacturing of algae biofuels will greatly benefit the U.S. economy and energy security, as well as society and the environment in general. Students and scholars at multi-levels, from middle school and high school students, to undergraduate and graduate students, and post-doc scholars and high school teachers have been trained on this project. Students from under-represented minority groups and female have participated in this project. New courses have been developed and numerous papers have been pubished to disseminate research results.
